<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime:
```c
void OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(uint32 msecs, struct timespec *tm)
{
    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, tm);

    /* add the delay to the current time */
    tm->tv_sec += (time_t)(msecs / 1000);
    /* convert residue ( msecs )  to nanoseconds */
    tm->tv_nsec += (msecs % 1000) * 1000000L;

    if (tm->tv_nsec >= 1000000000L)
    {
        tm->tv_nsec -= 1000000000L;
        tm->tv_sec++;
    }
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: I found no uses of compiler language extensions in the provided code. The function uses only standard C constructs and POSIX APIs: a function call (clock_gettime), a pointer to struct timespec, simple arithmetic, an explicit cast to time_t, integer literals with the standard long suffix (L), and member access (tm->tv_sec, tm->tv_nsec). The typedef uint32 references uint32_t which is a standard fixed-width integer type. There are no compiler-specific keywords or extensions present (for example no __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, __extension__, __int128, inline assembler, or other vendor-specific syntax). Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation for MISRA C:2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions).
